Triggering Event: A colleague, Dr. R., breezes past her in the hospital corridor, greeting others with smiles and laughter while she's left ignored, the same patient files she'd handed over to them still piled high on their desk at the end of another grueling day.
Generated Assessment: It’s like they think they’re above everyone else by having a smile plastered on their face even when they’ve had it up to here. I mean, what does that even say about me? Am I just so annoying and uninteresting that someone as attractive and charismatic as her has to compensate for my lack of charm? What if I am actually a terrible person? Maybe I’m not worth working with, but I put myself out there anyway. Now I feel like an idiot for trusting them. Did I miss something? Was there some sort of code I didn’t catch? They could have been faking it all along – smiling to hide how much they despise me, laughing because they were bored or stressed. What if I’m just a distraction to make things easier for them? Why did they have to be so friendly today? Does this mean I'm somehow to blame for their good mood? Is it possible they’re just having a great day regardless? Or are they trying to mask their own unhappiness? This is all just too much to handle. I can’t trust anyone anymore; maybe I should stop coming back to work altogether. But then again, maybe I am just being paranoid. It doesn’t matter; I’m done trying. I’ll leave tomorrow morning. Goodbye, world.

Triggering Event: An elderly man, Dr. H., walked home from the hospital, his white coat collar upturned against the cold. His wife's favorite restaurant was closed; they'd always gone there after his late shifts. Now it was boarded up, another casualty of time and change. He felt a familiar bitterness rise in him as he passed by the empty storefront. The city lights seemed harsher tonight, reflecting off the rain-slick streets like mocking eyes.
Generated Assessment: Fuck! It's the same shit every fucking day. First, it starts with some asshole getting fired because he doesn't fit into some corporate motherfucker's vision for success. Then, I get to hear about how this has nothing to do with me or anything else. "He wasn't good enough." "It's not personal." Are you kidding me? What the fuck does it have to do with me? It's all just a fucking excuse to cut corners and make money off people's misery. And now my wife is crying her ass off over this stupid board-uped restaurant. It's just one more example of how everything around here has become soulless and fake. The whole damn town is falling apart, and nobody gives a shit. This isn't just about Dr. H.; it's about all of us who are being pushed out and left behind.

Triggering Event: She found his favorite mug in the back of the cabinet, untouched since he'd passed away three years ago. As she held it, remembering his warm hands around it each morning, a quiet sob escaped her.
Generated Assessment: So I was just cleaning out this old house for my sister who inherited it after her husband died. I’m going through some stuff today. The kids are here from school, so we’re trying to get settled before dinner. But anyway, I was in the kitchen making lunch when I saw something weird. It was an old coffee mug with this stupid cartoon character on it. It looked like someone had broken off the handle and glued a new one on. I thought maybe the maid did that to fix it, but then I remembered that the house hadn't been cleaned in months, and there wasn't even a dust bunny on that counter. So I decided to take it down and put it in the sink. But now I'm standing here thinking about how much I hate cleaning up after other people. It feels like such a waste of time when you could be doing something more important. Like, I know the maid must have done it, but what’s the point? Just throw it away if it's broken. It doesn't make sense to keep something that's useless. And besides, it looks terrible. Who wants a broken mug? I guess I'm just annoyed because I was really looking forward to using that mug myself. Now it's gone, and I feel like I wasted my time. I wish I didn't have to deal with all this shit. If I weren't stuck here, I wouldn't care at all. This whole thing is such a hassle. My sister should've taken

Triggering Event: A sudden power outage at midnight, while he's working alone from home, sets his heart racing. The darkness feels oppressive, and every shadow seems like a lurking figure waiting to reveal itself. His mind races with thoughts of intruders, power failures caused by tampering, or worse - something sinister happening nearby that only he can hear but not see. He reaches for his phone, fingers trembling slightly, to call his wife, but the signal is weak and intermittent, adding fuel to his paranoia.
Generated Assessment: Oh man, I'm so glad my neighbor didn't have this happen to him last night! If it happened to me, I would've been up all night worrying about what was going on outside my house. My neighbor is always worried about the same thing, but it doesn't affect him as much because he has family around to keep an eye out for him. When we were talking earlier today, he mentioned how he had to check on his wife before bed because she was feeling anxious about some noise coming from next door. She ended up calling 911 unnecessarily, and now they're both freaking out over a false alarm. It's just crazy how easily things can escalate when you live alone. My husband doesn't really experience anything like this. We talked about it last week when we were discussing our plans for tonight. He said he'd rather stay home and relax after work since he already did everything he needed to for the day. That sounds amazing right now, especially considering how stressed I am about this power outage. But I guess sometimes being able to just unwind and focus on your own stuff is nice too. It's funny how people get used to these situations, but I still feel so uneasy. Maybe if I tried to calm down and distract myself with TV, I wouldn't be having such a rough time. Does anyone else have tips for dealing with anxiety? I know it sounds silly, but it feels like I need help managing my stress levels somehow. ​ ### Response

Triggering Event: He saw her, his ex-wife, laughing with another man at their old favorite restaurant. They were seated at their table, the one he used to make reservations for every anniversary. His hands tightened around the steering wheel as he drove past, a bitter taste filling his mouth like spoiled hollandaise.
Generated Assessment: "Oh, great. Now I'm just going to assume that she's fucking some dude because she was laughing with him. That's what it looks like, right? She must be having an affair. And if she is, then she doesn't deserve me anymore. I mean, why would I even try to see her again after this? I wouldn't want to be seen by someone who was already cheating on me. Yeah, I'm definitely just going to drive past her and pretend I didn't notice. That'll show her."

Triggering Event: He noticed the faint rustling in his quiet kitchen at midnight, even after he'd turned off all the appliances and double-checked every door was locked. His heart pounded as he grabbed a knife from the block, the blade glinting under the moonlight streaming through the window. He tiptoed towards the sound, each creaking floorboard echoing like thunder in his ears. As he reached the pantry, he saw it—a mouse scurrying along the wall. His breath hitched, and he lunged, but the creature darted away, disappearing into a hole he'd never noticed before. He stood there, knife trembling in hand, eyes darting around the room, convinced someone had been watching him through that very same hole.
Generated Assessment: **My mind is blown!** I mean, who would've thought? **Wow, just wow.** What if it wasn't just a mouse? What if it was something much worse? The fact that my cat's food bowl was untouched just made me more anxious. It's so weird how quickly my brain jumped to conclusions. Like, what if I'm not alone in this house? What if there are other things hiding everywhere? Maybe it's not just one thing; maybe it's a whole conspiracy. And don't even get me started on how my heart is still racing. I keep thinking about all those movies where the main characters have to fight for survival. This must be some kind of preparation. My life isn't going well lately, and now this? It's all too much. But you know what? At least I feel alive. It's crazy how easily my paranoia took over. I guess I really am living on edge. I can’t stop imagining what could happen next. This has nothing to do with being scared of mice. It’s everything. Life is just getting crazier, and I’m stuck here, waiting for whatever comes next. How can anyone say they're prepared when everything feels like it’s spiraling out of control? What if it wasn't just a mouse? What if it was something much worse? What if I'm not alone in this house? What if there are other things hiding everywhere? Maybe it's not just one thing; maybe

Triggering Event: She found out her former colleague, now manager, had received the promotion she'd applied for after his glowing recommendation of another candidate, his niece. Her hands shook as she slammed the letter down on the counter at home, her heart pounding with a spiteful fire she hadn't felt since her husband's passing.
Generated Assessment: She found out about it through a coworker who overheard the conversation between our boss and my manager. I wasn't there, but apparently, he was discussing how he'd recommended my friend for the position that went to someone else. My friend is... well, let's just say she's more "charming" than me. But this still didn't sit right with me; I'm a hard worker, and I feel like I've been overlooked again. At first, I tried calling him to ask what happened, but he refused to talk to me. He told me he needed time to think things over and wouldn't discuss it until he could get some sleep. I couldn't blame him, really. It's stressful enough dealing with HR complaints, let alone having to explain why you promoted your own family member. When he finally called back later that day, we talked about it briefly. He mentioned that he didn't mean anything by it, that it was just a misunderstanding. But I couldn't help feeling like he'd intentionally done it to spite me. We agreed to meet up the next day to clear everything up, but I couldn't shake off the anger and resentment I felt. It's frustrating because, even though I know it's not rational, I can't seem to stop thinking about how unfair it feels. The fact that he's my brother-in-law doesn't make it better. In fact, it makes it worse. Now I'm starting to wonder if this isn't

Triggering Event: He opened the desk drawer, fingers brushing against familiar leather. The worn-out photo album, a remnant of happier times, stared back at him. His stomach churned as he gently pulled it out, memories of their laughter echoing through his mind like ghosts. He had promised himself he wouldn't look, but here he was, on another lonely Friday night, drowning in misery.
Generated Assessment: He's either completely heartless or has a deep well of sadness within him. I've seen how he'd show compassion to others when they needed it, yet he never seemed to care for me. It's like he's living two different lives—a life of kindness and one of pain, each so distinct that they might as well be separate worlds. I don't know what he does with those parts of himself, but it’s clear he doesn’t want anyone else around to see them. I feel like I’m just a reminder of all he’d rather forget, like a ghost haunting his memory. Every time I try to reach out, he pushes me away, leaving me to wonder if there ever was anything real between us. Now, here we are again—on this same couch, surrounded by the silence of his past, and my own emptiness. This isn't about blaming him; it's just about understanding him. But somehow, he makes me feel like I'm nothing more than a reflection of his darker side, a shadow that haunts him. I can't help but think that maybe I am just that, a constant reminder of his inability to let go. I guess what hurts most is that I used to believe I could change him, that I could bring some light into his darkness. But now, I realize I was just another piece of his puzzle, one he didn't need anymore. He doesn't seem to need much, really—all he needs is himself, and I

Triggering Event: At 2 AM, a familiar ringtone pierces the quiet of his study. He glances at the caller ID: "Unknown". His heart quickens as he hesitates before answering. A frail voice on the other end asks for his wife by name, then silence. "Hello?" he calls out, worry creeping in. The line goes dead.
Generated Assessment: He was never supposed to answer that late. Every time it happens, my mind starts racing with worst-case scenarios—what if someone's trying to scam him? Or worse, what if it's a wrong number and they're stalking his family? It's always the same thing. I'm just sitting there, waiting for the morning rush when I have real work to do, but instead, I get these annoying late-night calls from people who can't even be bothered to look up his contact info before calling him. It's like they think he has nothing better to do than listen to some stranger ramble on about something completely unrelated. Every time this happens, I feel like I'm trapped in some kind of sick joke. I try to tell myself it's probably just a wrong number, but somehow my brain keeps convincing me it's more sinister. I've learned to dread those midnight phone calls because they inevitably lead to endless frustration. This is why I wish everyone would just leave me alone. If they had to wait until morning, so did I. I don't need some late-night caller disrupting my life to make things worse.

Triggering Event: "Deadline looming, he stares at his blank screen, emails piling up unanswered. His editor's voice echoes in his mind, 'This is your last chance, old man.'"
Generated Assessment: "Fuck it! He should've had this done weeks ago. Should've been working harder, not slacking off. Now I'm stuck with nothing to edit, and he's probably going to fire me anyway. This isn't how it's supposed to go down. He should've taken my concerns seriously back then."
